constellations_other.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_other.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

links.description: Shadow play sets were used in combination with magic lanterns to create horrifying shadow shows called phantasmagoria. F.W. Murnau’s Nosferatu merges this spooky, shadowy aesthetic with the moody darkness of German Expressionism to create the terrifying vampiric scenes.

end.title: Alan Wake
end.brief_description:
Presented in the style of a TV series, Alan Wake features the trademark Remedy storytelling and pulse-pounding action sequences. As players dive deeper and deeper into the mystery, they’ll face overwhelming odds, plot twists, and cliffhangers. It’s only by mastering the Fight With Light combat mechanic that they can stay one step ahead of the darkness that spreads across Bright Falls.

With the body of an action game and the mind of a psychological thriller, Alan Wake’s intense atmosphere, deep and multi-layered story, and exceptionally tense combat sequences provide players with an entertaining and original gaming experience.

end.title: Board games
end.brief_description: These were the television shows that became a part of our family, like relatives that came by to visit a few nights a week. There were hosts that audiences loved, guests they often didn’t and formats so recognisable they felt like a warm blanket. Board game versions of our most popular quiz shows were another way these programmes embedded themselves in our lives. The games allowed us to imagine finding a romantic partner on Perfect Match or walking away with cash prizes on The Price Is Right. Even as game-show formats changed on the small screen, the version inside the box lived on.

results.name: Oh, no! Beta!
results.description: The Sony Betacam BVP-3P was a broadcast-quality camera that used Sony's Beta system, most commonly found in consumer cameras. During the Format Wars in the 1970s and 80s, Beta lost to the cheaper and more accessible Video Home System (VHS).

key_work.title: Sony Betacam BVP-3P
key_work.brief_description: Sony introduced the professional use Betacam cassette format in 1982 for the broadcast video industry. Although related to the Betamax format, its key differences were consumer orientated as it competed against VHS (Video Home System) in the videotape format wars of the period.

The show has also made name for itself in its fearless satirical take on politics, media and American life in general.

end.title: The Ferals [Puppets]
end.credit_line:
Designed by Garth Frost

Puppet maker Tina Matthews

Australia, 1993

Courtesy of Emma de Vries

Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020
end.brief_description: “They discovered fame and fortune and they’re never going back.” Or so proclaimed the catchy hook of The Ferals TV theme song. This kids’ program debuted on ABC TV in 1994 and then, after two successful seasons, it has endured in Australian pop culture. Capitalising on the grunge aesthetic of the time, it followed an unruly bunch of feral animals living in a share house with flatmates played by human actors. The ditzy rabbit Mixy and sassy cat Modigliana were key members of the show, adding to the tradition of children’s programming featuring puppets in starring roles, including Lift Off (1992-95) and Mr Squiggle (1959-99).

links.description: While Blinky Bill was the cuddly kind of marsupial, the animals in The Ferals are anything but. These edgy, punk-rock rodents and cats still managed to strike a chord with audiences and were beloved by kids in the 1990s.

results.name: Landscape as character
results.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

key_work.title: Landscape as Character
key_work.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

start.title: Landscape as Character
start.brief_description: The Australian landscape is never just a setting. It’s meditative, motivational and menacing; a character that empowers, intimidates and inspires. This artwork examines how representations of Australian landscapes have evolved from being dominated by the Outback to the suburbs and cities.

end.brief_description: In 1825, Claire, a young Irish convict, enlists an Indigenous tracker to chase a British soldier through the rugged Tasmanian wilderness, bent on revenge for a terrible act of violence he committed against her family.

constellations_other.name: David Dalaithngu
constellations_other.description: David Dalaithngu was a Yolngu man of the Mandhalpuyngu speech of the Djinba language. As a young boy, Dalaithngu was an accomplished hunter, tracker and dancer, which he turned into an acclaimed film career that saw him win the Best Actor award at the Cannes Film Festival (for Charlie's Country) and an AACTA for The Tracker, among his many honours.

links.description: An Indigenous guide also leads the audience through white prejudice, oppression and brutality in Jennifer Kent’s The Nightingale, where the oppressed First Peoples man Billy (Baykali Ganambarr) and Irish convict Claire (Aisling Franciosi), chase British forces into a labyrinthine bush that represents the latter’s demise.

In their colorful bus, Priscilla, the three performers travel across the Australian desert performing for enthusiastic crowds and homophobic locals.

constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

recommendations.quote: The film's three leads have all swapped fabulous frocks for villainous outfits in superhero films. Terrance Stamp was Zod in Superman 2, Hugo Weaving was Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger and Guy Pearce was Aldrich Killian in Iron Man 3.

links.description: The Outback is again a place of prejudice in The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, with the queer crew of the famous bus confronted by small-mind mentalities. But the desert is also a source of hope and freedom, with the characters finding common humanity and community on the road.

The show has also made name for itself in its fearless satirical take on politics, media and American life in general.

links.description: During Waterworld‘s troubled production, Buffy the Vampire Slayer creator Joss Whedon was flown to the set and spent seven “weeks of hell” doing rewrites on the script, in which he “accomplished nothing”.

start.title: Cartoon connections
start.brief_description: The Simpsons and Dragon’s Lair arcade cabinets symbolise how cartoons, animation techniques and videogames have enjoyed a symbiotic relationship throughout their development.

constellations_primary.name: Cartoon classics and criticism
constellations_primary.description: A whole cavalcade of cartoons have successfully made the leap into arcades and onto consoles, but the relationship between cinema and videogames is far more likely to fizzle out.

end.title: The Simpsons
end.brief_description: Set in Springfield, the average American town, the show focuses on the antics and everyday adventures of the Simpson family; Homer, Marge, Bart, Lisa and Maggie, as well as a virtual cast of thousands. Since the beginning, the series has been a pop culture icon, attracting hundreds of celebrities to guest star. The show has also made name for itself in its fearless satirical take on politics, media and American life in general.

constellations_other.name: Migrations
constellations_other.description: Universal Everything's Migrations features fantastical creatures born from elements of other animals, just like the titles in this Constellation.

constellations_other.name: Oh, no! Beta!
constellations_other.description: The Sony Betacam BVP-3P was a broadcast-quality camera that used Sony's Beta system, most commonly found in consumer cameras. During the Format Wars in the 1970s and 80s, Beta lost to the cheaper and more accessible Video Home System (VHS).

constellations_other.name: Transformations
constellations_other.description: Like many techniques born from the visual language of magic lanterns, the dissolve effect was incorporated into filmmaking and is still used today.

links.description: The Simpsons arcade in the Cartoon connections display is based on the longest-running sitcom in TV history – The Simpsons, which has been screening since 1989. It’s also been the basis of over 25 videogames!

end.title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles
end.brief_description: The player chooses from one of the four Ninja Turtles: Leonardo, Michelangelo, Donatello, and Raphael. After Shredder kidnaps the Turtles’ friend April O’Neil and their mentor Splinter, they must give chase, save their comrades, and defeat the evil Shredder.

links.description: Two years before Konami made The Simpsons arcade game, they translated another popular cartoon into an arcade videogame – Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. The two games feature the same game mechanics and almost identical play style.

key_work.brief_description: A cameraman wanders around Moscow, Kharkiv, Kyiv and Odesa with a camera slung over his shoulder, documenting urban life with dazzling invention.

start.title: Chronicle of a Summer
start.creator_credit: Edgar Morin, Anatole Dauman and Philippe Lifchitz
start.brief_description: Anthropologist and filmmaker Jean Rouch, along with sociologist and film critic Edgar Morin, both assisted by Marceline and Nadine, roam the crowded streets asking ordinary people how they deal with the misfortunes of life.

constellations_other.name: Film-truth
constellations_other.description: The experimental documentary Man with a Movie Camera has had a lasting impact on the development of film styles.

end.title: Gimme Shelter
end.brief_description: The landmark documentary about the tragically ill-fated Rolling Stones free concert at Altamont Speedway on December 6, 1969. Only four months earlier, Woodstock defined the Love Generation; now it lay in ruins on a desolate racetrack six miles outside of San Francisco.

constellations_other.name: Film-truth
constellations_other.description: The experimental documentary Man with a Movie Camera has had a lasting impact on the development of film styles.

links.description: In the US, Direct Cinema grew out of a similar methodology. Brothers Albert and David Maysles were key proponents of the style and their film Gimme Shelter (co-directed with Charlotte Zwerin) chronicled the Rolling Stones’ concert tour that culminated in the disastrous Altamont Free Concert in 1969.

end.title: Grey Gardens
end.creator_credit: Muffie Meyer, Albert Maysles and David Maysles
end.brief_description: Edie Bouvier Beale and her mother, Edith, two aging, eccentric relatives of Jackie Kennedy Onassis, are the sole inhabitants of a Long Island estate. The women reveal themselves to be misfits with outsized, engaging personalities. Much of the conversation is centered on their pasts, as mother and daughter now rarely leave home.

constellations_other.name: Reality TV me
constellations_other.description: Cult documentary Grey Gardens follows the everyday eccentricities of mother and daughter Big Edie and Little Edie. The women perform and speak candidly to the camera, and have been described as predecessors to reality TV stars.

constellations_other.name: Film-truth
constellations_other.description: The experimental documentary Man with a Movie Camera has had a lasting impact on the development of film styles.

links.description: The Maysles brothers’ follow up, Grey Gardens (co-directed with Ellen Hovde and Muffie Meyer), is a well-known example of the fly-on-the-wall style of filming, prompting the film’s eccentric and insightful subjects to reveal a portrait of themselves.

links.description: In the 1960s, the concept of Kino-Pravda, or “film truth” inspired the cinema verite movement, which described an observational or ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style of filmmaking, as seen in Jean Rouch’s Chronicle of a Summer.

links.description: Prior to Man with a Movie Camera, couple Dziga Vertov and Elisaveta Svilova made a series of newsreels entitled Kino-Pravda. Meaning film-truth, their methodology espoused the ability of the camera to capture the truth of everyday life.

end.title: Letter to Jane
end.creator_credit: Jean-Pierre Gorin
end.brief_description: The film’s subject is a photograph of Jane Fonda visiting Hanoi during the Vietnam War. It asks what the position of the intellectual should be in the class struggle and points out the irony of Jane Fonda’s participation in the photo shoot, which was staged.

constellations_other.name: Film-truth
constellations_other.description: The experimental documentary Man with a Movie Camera has had a lasting impact on the development of film styles.

links.description: With a revitalised interest in Vertov’s work (and Svilova’s contribution overlooked), the Dziga Vertov Group was founded in 1968. Letter to Jane is a cinematic essay exploring a photograph of Jane Fonda protesting the Vietnam War.
